content: Am delving into type theory and am trying to come up with a formulation of catamorphisms in Lean. I'm wondering, what is the type-theoretical reason we can't formulate Haskell's Fix f = f (Fix f) in Lean? I know this has something to do with enforcing totality, but is there a way to formulate this more formally by comparing Lean and Haskell's type theories?
The answer is presumably (A -> A) -> A, but if you substitute A := False then you can immediately prove false from it
